title: Apple will require masks for customers and employees in many U.S. stores.
snippet: Apple had lifted mask requirements in its American stores earlier this year, but the Delta variant prompted it to reverse course.

title: Apple’s profits nearly doubled in the latest quarter.
snippet: The pandemic has been a windfall for Apple and its peers, as people buy even more gadgets to work, study and socialize.

title: Can Apple’s AirTags Find Lost Pets?
snippet: We look at the pros and cons of using Apple’s AirTag tracking device to find our missing dogs and cats.

title: Apple delays its return to office as the Delta variant surges.
snippet: Employees are now expected to come back to the workplace as early as October, a month later than planned.

title: Poem: The Woman You Love Cuts Apples for You
snippet: Reading Rosal’s poem again made me pull out some tajin, and slice some apples, and remember how poems create a heart’s history and remind us of home.

title: Catch up: Deutsche Bank beat expectations; Apple, Google and Microsoft had very profitable quarters.
The F.T.C. votes to use its leverage to make it easier for consumers to repair their phones.
snippet: An advocacy group for technology companies criticized the move by the commission, saying it would jeopardize the safety of consumers.

title: Big Tech Has Outgrown This Planet
snippet: The gap keeps widening between the super rich tech superstars and the merely super. There’s one possible explanation.

title: Credit to Tech’s Pandemic Leadership
snippet: America’s tech companies have been leading the way for how large employers should aid in the country’s pandemic response.

title: Delays, More Masks and Mandatory Shots: Virus Surge Disrupts Office-Return Plans
snippet: A wave of the contagious Delta variant is causing companies to reconsider when they will require employees to return, and what health requirements should be in place when they do.

title: Stocks drop ahead of tech earnings.
Here’s what happened in the markets today.
Quotation of the Day: Virus Surge Complicates Return-to-Office Plans
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 24, 2021.

title: Lyft pushes office return date to February as Twitter closes offices it had reopened.
snippet: A jump in virus cases has many companies rethinking their plans.

title: Ross Douthat Has Been ‘Radicalized a Little Bit, Too’
snippet: We debate the recent G.O.P. voting bills and how to teach racism in the context of U.S. history.

title: This Conversation Will Change How You Think About Thinking
snippet: Modern work culture is built on a broken model of the mind.

title: In ‘Mr. Corman,’ Joseph Gordon-Levitt Looks Inward and Asks, ‘What If?’
snippet: For his new Apple TV+ comedy series, Gordon-Levitt imagined what his life might have been like if he hadn’t been so lucky. “It’s probably the most me-ish thing I’ve ever made.”

title: How the pandemic became ‘a pot of gold for tech.’
How Blue Cities Became So Outrageously Unaffordable
snippet: How the party of big government became the party of paralysis.

title: Caeleb Dressel leads the U.S. to victory in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
snippet: Results from the men’s 4x100-meter freestyle relay.

title: Star swimmer Katie Ledecky feels the sting of a first Olympic loss.
snippet: In the 400-meter freestyle she was something of an underdog. But she had never lost at the Olympics until Monday.

title: In ‘Ted Lasso,’ Juno Temple Makes Nice
snippet: Best known for playing troubled (and troubling) young women onscreen, the actor has found acclaim and a gift for comedy in this warmhearted soccer sitcom.

title: Biden to Name a Critic of Big Tech as the Top Antitrust Cop
snippet: Jonathan Kanter, a longtime antitrust lawyer, has built his career largely around working for smaller rivals of Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple.

title: Wearing Masks Indoors Again? Some States Are a Vehement No.
snippet: After the C.D.C. advised masking indoors in areas with high rates of Covid-19, some locales went back under mask mandates. But there was also defiance and hostility.

title: The Latest Target of Hong Kong’s Crackdown: Children’s Books
snippet: A story that portrayed the police as wolves helped lead to the arrests of five leaders of a speech therapists’ union.

title: Stocks push further into record territory ahead of Big-Tech earnings.
Robot Therapists? Not So Fast, Says Talkspace C.E.O.
snippet: Oren Frank argues that the future of therapy is still in the hands of humans. But what does tech-enabled therapy mean for privacy and your data?

title: Hank Paulson raises more than $5 billion for a climate-focused private equity fund.
Meet the Man Who Wants You to Give Up Google
snippet: Sridhar Ramaswamy ran the tech giant’s lucrative ad machine. Now he’s betting on a new business model for search.

title: What Happens if There’s a Covid Outbreak at the Olympics?
snippet: Kara Swisher finds out why the 2020 Tokyo Games are still on for 2021 and who might be held accountable if they become a superspreader event.

title: So Close to Returning to Offices, Companies Upend Plans Again
snippet: Large businesses are revising their rules about employee vaccinations and wearing masks as the Delta variant drives up infections.

title: We Need a New Term for Video Games
snippet: We’re seeing a ton of new games, and many of them blur the lines between video games and other types of activities.

title: Facebook’s profit surges 101 percent on strong ad sales.
snippet: Advertising revenue, which continues to be the bulk of Facebook’s income, rose 56 percent to $28.6 billion, easily surpassing Wall Street expectations.

title: ‘Lorelei’ Review: A Rural Melodrama, Lost at Sea
snippet: Pablo Schreiber and Jena Malone attempt to provide an anchor for this listless character drama.

title: Many return-to-office plans are being disrupted by the virus surge.
‘How It Ends’ Review: What, You Expected Us to Tell You?
snippet: In this apocalyptic comedy, Zoe Lister-Jones and Daryl Wein count down Earth’s last day, measuring out the hours in serial conflict resolutions.

title: ‘Tailgate’ Review: Retribution for Road Rage
snippet: In this Dutch thriller, a man puts his family in danger by refusing to apologize to a serial killer with a pious streak.

title: Catch up: Big Tech’s streak of profits continues, but investors expected more.
‘The New Bauhaus’ Review: Rethinking an Approach to Art
snippet: This documentary on the interdisciplinary artist Laszlo Moholy-Nagy makes the case that he should be a household name.

title: ‘It’s a Tough Time to Be Mayor’: Lori Lightfoot Responds to Her Critics
snippet: The mayor of Chicago talks about the city’s Covid response, why she doesn’t support the defund-the-police movement and her controversial efforts to improve newsroom diversity.

title: Uber delays its return to office and will require vaccines for employees.
Katie Ledecky Feels the Sting of a First Olympic Loss
snippet: In the 400-meter freestyle, she was something of an underdog. But she had never lost at the Olympics until Monday.

title: ‘Enemies of the State’ Review: Seeking Proof Shrouded in Shadows
snippet: This documentary on the strange case of Matt DeHart weaves uncertainty into its structure.

title: Sarah Niles Needed ‘Ted Lasso,’ Too
snippet: Like a lot of the show’s fans, the British actress found the fish-out-of-water comedy to be an emotional balm during an exceptionally trying time. Now she’s the latest big addition to the cast.

title: ‘Settlers’ Review: Interstellar Colonialism on Mars
snippet: The first feature from Wyatt Rockefeller takes on exploitation and violence against women — and bungles both.

title: ‘Ride the Eagle’ Review: A Nontoxic Bro Faces Midlife Lessons
snippet: A conga-playing, marijuana-smoking man approaches middle age — and romance — with help from a video from his mother.

title: What’s Really Behind the 1619 Backlash? An Interview With Nikole Hannah-Jones and Ta-Nehisi Coates.
snippet: The award-winning writers discuss the 1619 Project, American democracy and Donald Trump.

title: Eviction ban ends, Robinhood goes public, and the Fed meets: What’s coming this week.
Carl Levin, the Senate Scourge of Corporate America, Dies at 87
snippet: The longest-serving U.S. senator in Michigan history, Mr. Levin was regarded by colleagues and Washington observers as a paragon of probity.

title: We’re Going Back to the Office. Should We?
snippet: Over the past year, the white-collar workplace as we know it has changed drastically. And maybe it should stay that way.
